chapter.title: Skeleton Generator

chapter.para:
Skeleton Generator
When you are writing tests for existing code, you have to write the same code fragments such as public function testMethod() { } over and over again. PHPUnit can help you by analyzing the code of the existing class and generating a skeleton test-case class for it.

example.title: The Calculator class
example.programlisting:
<?php
class Calculator
{
    public function add($a, $b)
    {
        return $a + $b;
    }
}
?>

chapter.para: The following example shows how to generate a skeleton test class for a class named Calculator (see ).
chapter.screen:
phpunit --skeleton Calculator PHPUnit 3.2.10 by Sebastian Bergmann.
Wrote test class skeleton for Calculator to CalculatorTest.php.
chapter.para:
Incomplete Test
For each method in the original class, there will be an incomplete test-case (see ) in the generated test-case class.
Below is the output of running the generated test-case class.
chapter.screen:
phpunit --verbose CalculatorTest PHPUnit 3.2.10 by Sebastian Bergmann.
CalculatorTest I
Time: 0 seconds
There was 1 incomplete test:
1) testAdd(CalculatorTest) This test has not been implemented yet. /home/sb/CalculatorTest.php:54
OK, but incomplete or skipped tests! Tests: 1, Incomplete: 1.

section.title: Annotations
section.para:
Annotation @assert
You can use @assert annotation in the documentation block of a method to automatically generate simple, yet meaningful tests instead of incomplete test-cases.
shows an example.

example.title: The Calculator class with @assert annotations
example.programlisting:
<?php
class Calculator
{
    /**
     * @assert (0, 0) == 0
     * @assert (0, 1) == 1
     * @assert (1, 0) == 1
     * @assert (1, 1) == 2
     */
    public function add($a, $b)
    {
        return $a + $b;
    }
}
?>

section.para: Below is the output of running the generated test-case class.
section.screen:
phpunit CalculatorTest PHPUnit 3.2.10 by Sebastian Bergmann.
....
Time: 0 seconds
OK (4 tests)
section.para: shows the supported variations of the @assert annotation and how they are transformed into test code.
